de.humatic.nmj

Class NMJConfig

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.humatic.nmj.NMJConfig

  • public class NMJConfig
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the main configuration interface for nmj network MIDI channels. Configuration is stored in SharedPreferences and will be recalled on subsequent library loadings without requiring further interaction. The class is used to define how many and what kind of channels you want your application to have available. Typically this means defining some defaults on an application's first run and then reading those out on subsequent launches. On top of such application defined channels, this class also manages some automatic discovery options and will provide info on and access to channels that may get created when network services are popping up or Usb devices become available.
    Long as an application did not set any preferences, nmj will default to three IP based channels (two RAW / multicast channels and one local RTP session). These are merely defaults that you can modify or overwrite to your needs.


    Channels are primarily defined by the following properties:

    Mode - the basic technology and / or protocol used (see below)
    Name - User friendly name string to present in UIs
    IP - An IP address, device path or other resource identifier
    Port - Remote port number or mode specific index value
    Local Port - Local port number or vendor and product IDs depending on channel mode

    All these properties have getter and setter methods (setMode(..)/getMode(..), setName(..)/getName(..) etc.), which are used to define an applications MIDI options.
    To raise the number of channels use addChannel() or setNumChannels(). Note that accessing channels with invalid indices will throw NMJExceptions. So will attempts to call setters on channels that are currently open and in active use.


    Supported operation modes:

    RAW - this runs raw MIDI bytes over IP, can run both uni- and multicast and is compatible with ipMidi and Midi2Net. Default settings match those of ipMIDI channels 0 - n.

    RTPA - uses RTP for transport and Apple's Network MIDI protocol for session establishment. A channel can either operate in server mode, offering a device local session for other peers to connect to or act as a client to remote sessions. Configurationwise this is controlled via the IP field (getIP(..) / setIP(..)): a device local session has an IP value of null, while a client session stores the remote host's IP address. Local sessions are announced via DNS, remote sessions may be picked up via DNS, but can equally be configured manually.
    A channel representing a local session needs to be opened to be visible to remote peers. The actual network connections is then made from the remote side. Connections to remote sessions are made when the corresponding nmj channel is opened.

    BLUETOOTH - runs raw MIDI bytes over Bluetooth RFCOMM using one of four custom service UUIDs. Bluetooth channels need to be configured by the application. Once opened they will make the Android device act as a server broadcasting the availability of MIDI services for PC side implementations to pick up on standard Bluetooth device and service queries. Connections are always made from the PC side.
    Note: This is a proprietary implementation running on outdated technology. Not recommended for use in 3rd party software. No guarantees are made for ongoing availability.

    DSMI - enables use of the DSMIDIWifiServer on the computer side. DSMI originally stands for a Nintendo DS MIDI interface open source project that has been around for quite a while. DSMI uses broadcast addresses and assumes that all MIDI messages are 3 bytes long. Handle with care.

    ADB - runs MIDI over the Android Debug Bridge normally using wired Usb connections. The Android device will always be a client to the PC side implementation. ADB channels need to be configured by the application and will then be announced when the PC side scans for ADB channels. Connections are always made from the PC side.
    Note: This is a hack to provide much asked for direct Usb connectivity. It requires that users enable Usb debugging on their devices. Not recommended for use in 3rd party software. No guarantees are made for ongoing availability.

    USB_HOST - for use with class-compliant Usb MIDI interfaces. USB_HOST channels are created when the presence of a class-compliant Usb MIDI interface is detected and the user has given permission to the application to access the device. You can not manually configure USB_HOST channels. Requires Android 3.1 and vendor support for host mode.

    MWS - runs MIDI over WebSockets, optionally encoding it following RTP standards. This is much like the RTPA mode in terms of client / server operation and service discovery so the information given above applies here as well. Main differences are in session establishment and the transport layer: While plain RTP runs on UDP, WebSocket traffic uses TCP. UDP does not guarantee packet delivery, data loss can and will happen. This should mostly be ruled out with WebSockets, but it may be bought with higher overall latency and jitter. This mode requires Android 2.2 or greater. No guarantees are made for ongoing availability.

    COM - Raw serial MIDI over (some) Usb COM interfaces. This is experimental, incomplete and may go away without notice. There is no standardized Usb device class for serial interfaces. Implementations need to take care of vendor and device specific requirements, which is not going to be the case with all interfaces here. Usb devices with more than one port are likely to fail miserably. nmj will check whether detected FTDI adapters are actually serial interfaces on Enttec Usb Pro or Cinetix DMX 512 boxes and if they turn out to be, MIDI CCs and Notes on MIDI channels 1-4 will set levels on 512 DMX channels.

      • USB_DEVICE_ATTACHED

        public static final java.lang.String USB_DEVICE_ATTACHED
        Broadcast action that should be send from USB_DEVICE_ATTACHED springboard activities to trigger a device query. Global USB_ATTACHMENT_LISTEN flag needs to be set or no receiver will be registered.

      • edit

        @Deprecated
public static void edit(android.content.Context parent)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Deprecated. 
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • edit

        public static void edit(android.content.Context parent,
        boolean clear)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Opens the SharedPreferences for editing in the given context without initializing the MIDI system itself. Also see NetworkMidiSystem.get().
        Parameters:
        parent - - the application context
        clear - - clear all existing nmj preferences. It seems like Android M does not fully remove all preference files on app uninstall. As edit(...) is primarily meant for initial setup, it assumes that it will be starting from zero, which does not seem to be guaranteed on M. This option will make the library perform a full wipe of all eventually left data after getting the SharedPreferences and the Editor.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setProperty

        public static void setProperty(java.lang.String key,
               java.lang.String value)

      • getProperty

        public static java.lang.String getProperty(java.lang.String key,
                           java.lang.String def)

      • setNumChannels

        public static void setNumChannels(int nr)
        Sets the total number of channels that the library will provide, calling through to setNumChannels(int nr, boolean clear) with the boolean parameter set to true.

      • setNumChannels

        public static void setNumChannels(int nr,
                  boolean clear)
        Sets the total number of channels that the library will provide. If the new number is smaller than the currently set number of channels, configuration data for those channels no longer needed is optionally deleted and channels newly created after this will be initialized with default settings.

      • addChannel

        public static int addChannel()
        Increments the channel count by 1 and returns the newly created channel's id.

      • getNumChannels

        public static int getNumChannels()
        Returns the total number of channels that the library is configured to provide. This may change during runtime when remote channels are discovered or go out of scope.

      • cleanup

        public static int[] cleanup(int defChannels,
            int[] protectedChannels)
        Deletes all remote channels discovered during runtime from defChannels+1 onward unless their current indices are present in %protectedChannels. If they are, channels are stored with new subsequent indices and those new indices are returned so you can update your storage. This would typically be called in onDestroy() after NetworkMidiSystem.exit().
        Parameters:
        defChannels - - the number of channels that an app defines and always wants to keep.
        protectedChannels - - indices of remote channels that you may have opened and want to keep as well, can be of zero length.
        Returns:
        - returns new indices for protected channels

      • setLocalPort

        public static void setLocalPort(int ch,
                int port)
                         throws NMJException
        Sets the local port number for the given channel (unicast mode only).
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getLocalPort

        public static int getLocalPort(int ch)
                        throws NMJException
        Returns a channel's local port.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setBasePort

        public static void setBasePort(int mode,
               int p)
        Sets the port number that local ports for the given channel mode will be based on (first channel will use p and p+1, channel n will use p+n*2 and p+n*2+1). Relevant only for RTP, MWS and ADB channels. There should be no need to change this unless you want to run two programs making use of nmj in parallel on on machine / device. In that case call this once in the very beginning after NetworkMIDISystem.get(..). If you plan to publish an app based on nmj please request and subsequently use a base port number to ensure that your program doesn't conflict with others.

      • setMode

        public static void setMode(int ch,
           int mode)
                    throws NMJException,
                           java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                           java.lang.SecurityException
        Sets a channel's operation mode, ie. the technology and / or protocol it will use to connect with remote devices.
        Throws:
        NMJException
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        java.lang.SecurityException

      • getRTPState

        public static int getRTPState(int ch)

        public static int getMode(int ch)
                   throws NMJException
        Returns the channel's general operation mode (RAW, RTP, BLUETOOTH etc.).
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setNetworkAdapter

        public static void setNetworkAdapter(int ch,
                     int index)
                              throws NMJException
        Sets the network interface to bind sockets to by index into the enumeration returned from java.net.NetworkInterface.getNetworkInterfaces(). This is usually not required as the library will attempt to figure out what the default adapter is, but on multi-homed systems it may be necessary or desired to specify the network adapter for multicast channels.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getNetworkAdapter

        public static int getNetworkAdapter(int ch)
                             throws NMJException
        Returns the index of the channel's explicitly set or default network interface.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • canOpen

        public static boolean canOpen(int ch)
        Checks whether the available connectivity will allow the given channel to be opened

      • setIO

        public static void setIO(int ch,
         int io)
                  throws NMJException
        Sets the given (RAW/multicast) channel to input (0) or output (1). Does nothing for other channels.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • getIO

        public static int getIO(int ch)
                 throws NMJException
        Returns 0 if the given channel is set as an input, 1 for output and -1 for bidirectional channels.
        Throws:
        NMJException

      • setFlags

        public static void setFlags(int ch,
            int flags)
        Controls additional aspects, like auto connection settings, service discovery etc. For global flags use -1 for the channel parameter.

      • getFlags

      • getConnectivity

        public static int getConnectivity(android.content.Context ctx)

      • addHotspotChannels

        public static int addHotspotChannels(int count,
                     int basePort)
        Adds %count RTP channels referencing sessions on an Android hotspot IF the running instance is logged into a WIFI network provided by such a hotspot. Multicast DNS does not work over the hotspot, these channels would otherwise need to be added manually. Returns number of channels added, which may be less than count in case there were channels that had previously been added or -1 if no hotspot network was detected.
